facts.text: This is an appeal from a judgment of the High Court at Calcutta in a reference under Section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from a judgment of the High Court at Calcutta in a reference under Section 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: The respondent, Messrs. Isthmian Steamship Lines is a company incorporated in the United States of America.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Messrs. Isthmian Steamship Lines  hereinafter referred to as the companypany  is a companypany incorporated in the United States of America

facts.text: The company owns steamships which visit India.

facts.text: The company's Indian profits are computed on the basis of day on round voyage and assessed to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act as a company through its agents, Messrs. Angus Co., Ltd.

facts.text: In the course of the assessment for the years 1941-42, 1942-43 and 1943-44, the company claimed that its unabsorbed depreciation at the end of 1938-39 should be deemed to be a part of the depreciation allowance for 1939-40 and carried forward under Section 10(2)(vi).

anchor.surface_text: In the course of the assessment for the years 1941-42, 1942-43 and 1943-44, the companypany claimed that its unabsorbed depreciation at the end of 1938-39 should be deemed to be a part of the depreciation allowance for 1939-40 and therefore such unabsorbed depreciation should be allowed to be further carried forward under Section 10 2   vi  of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: The claim was negatived by the Income-tax Officer, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: This claim was negatived by the Income-tax Officer, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: The Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal however, at the instance of the companypany, referred the following question to the High Court for its opinion -

facts.text: The question referred: Whether the Tribunal was right in holding that the unabsorbed depreciation at the end of 1938-39 could not be treated as part of the allowable depreciation for 1941-42, 1942-43, 1943-44.

facts.text: The High Court answered the question in favour of the company.

facts.text: The High Court gave a certificate to the Commissioner of Income-tax under Section 66A(2) to appeal to this Court.

anchor.surface_text: and gave a certificate to the Commissioner of Income-tax under Section 66A 2  of the Act to appeal to this Court and hence this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to amended s.10(2)(vi) excludes only years ending prior to 1 April 1939; dates apply to assessment years; 1939-40 ends 31 March 1940 so allowable; profits insufficient to absorb hence carry forward permitted

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this view is based on a misreading of the section. The words used in the section are - where full effect cannot be given, and not where full effect has not been given. It is not denied that the profits or gains were less than the depreciation allowance, and that being so the requirements of the section were satisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section uses prospective 'cannot be given' not retrospective 'has not been given'; undisputed that profits insufficient

They must be held to apply to the assessment year, because in income-tax matters the law to be applied is the law in force in the assessment year unless otherwise stated or implied.
In our opinion, this question has been rightly answered by the High Court in favour of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The first question which arises is whether the assessment year 1939-40 is an assessment year which ended prior to the 1st of April, 1939. It is evident that it is not, because it ended on the 31st of March, 1940.
In our opinion, this question has been rightly answered by the High Court in favour of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer refused to allow that amount, but, for the reasons already stated, we have to disregard that fact and therefore, for the purpose of the present reference, must treat the unabsorbed depreciation which was carried forward from the assessment year 1938-39 into the accounts of the assessment year 1939-40 as the unabsorbed depreciation in the assessment year 1939-40
In our opinion, this question has been rightly answered by the High Court in favour of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this view is based on a misreading of the section. The words used in the section are - where full effect cannot be given, and not where full effect has not been given. It is not denied that the profits or gains were less than the depreciation allowance, and that being so the requirements of the section were satisfied.
In our opinion, this question has been rightly answered by the High Court in favour of the assessee.
